reviews.text:
During our time in Barcelona, my wife and I enjoyed visiting the various historical sites located throughout this iconic European city. We particularly enjoyed our guided tour of Hospital Sant Pau. This complex, which was built between 1901 and 1930, appeared to be more of a charming, welcoming village than a hospital complex. I learned that this hospital, which was still in operation up until 2009, was purposely constructed to be a welcoming and warm place for patients. The buildings have lots of glass which bring in light from sunshine and the interiors appear to be built for comfort as well as maximizing excellent patient care. From the Administration Building to the Operating Building as well as the other buildings are still well maintained and are now a museum. In addition, one of the large rooms within the complex is now utilized for musical performances. I can only imagine how special those performances must be.

If only more hospitals around the world would be able to provide the high level of care provided by this hospital including a location on such a magnificent campus.

I read that this is a more recent attraction that sits high on the list of MUST DOs when visiting Barcelona.  It was our early afternoon attraction sandwiched between some Gaudi visits.  A tough act to follow, I I was totally blown away!  The photos  are amazing, but do not to it justice.
It was only a short walk from our apartment, so we were lucky enough to see it lit up at night as well.  Sant Pau continues as a work in progress and is in the grounds of a fully functioning hospital, some areas of which are still in these amazing old buildings.
Given what I'd read about it, we decided not to buy tickets in advance and that proved to be a good decision.  The tourist traffic was quite low, but I'm sure this will change as more people become aware of it.

We visited Recinte Modernista de Sant Pau, a beautiful complex of Modernist buildings designed by Lluis Domenech I Montaner, on Sunday when it was free but I gladly would have paid the admission to see this amazing complex. The Metro delivered us to the modern Hospital de Sant Pau, and from there it was a rather long but fortunately downhill walk to the Modernist complex. The buildings were even more beautiful than I had anticipated and the displays of medical equipment and explanations of treatment practices were interesting. Try to work a visit to this site into your plans if you can!

We spotted this from the tour bus and went back to see the set of Woody Allen's Vick Cristina Barcelona for ourselves! The 'new' hospital offers audio tours so you can stroll the area which has a dozen hospital buildings with ornate Moorish roofs and art nouveau stonework and appreciate some of the interiors to see for yourself the use of light and colour. The progressive hopsital had operating theatres, light and bright day rooms and an underground network to transport patients. This was a really educational tour and a real celebration of the art nouveau movement. Well worth a visit.

Lovely buildings...we were staying in an apartment across the street. Very impressive, and never talked about in tourist guides. A four block walk from the Sagrada Familia...find a walking video to find the way.
Worth a look!

When you enter it is like a palace , an art nouveau treasure . It is amazing also, that it was only closed down some 20 years ago when the modern new hospital was opened.
When we were there in January very few other visitors unlike the Segrada.

The buildings were lovely, great to photograph. Some sections were closed for maintenance and there wasn't very much inside the buildings. Nice to stroll through, but there are better attractions in Barcelona.

Highly recommended to include in the itinerary when visiting Barcelona. Beautiful and colorful old buildings and structures is a feast for the eyes. Just quite weird to imagine that it used to be a hospital. Better come when the sun is not yet very high so you can take amazing pictures outdoor. The ceilings are also amazing.

We were in Barcelona to visit the Sagrada but with time to spare we wandered and after coffee discovered Sant Pau. At the time of out visit it was hosting Barcelona Fashion Week so the people were an added fascination. This place however is amazing,  the architecture the history and indeed the whole original concept as with the Sagrada however description of the experience is both personal and difficult but certainly unforgettable.

My wife read about this site on Atlas Obscura and it looked very interesting. The facility was unbelievably stunning in all ways! It was built to be a hospital for the poor and it was more like a palace. It took many years to build and millions of dollars. It was a functioning hospital not to long ago. Parts have been restored and brought back to it original self and there is still more work to be done. The detail that went into this is truly remarkable. We spent roughly three and a half hours there. I highly recommend you get an audio guide and enjoy.
One of the most amazing experiences in Barcelona, unexpected, unique, words can't describe how ART NOUVEAU and a real hospital experience mix. An example of avant-garde thinking and acting. A must!!

A hospital village built from 1910-1930 and in use till 2003! Domènech i Montaner is the architect. Several pavilions can be visited. Beautiful arts dec decorations everywhere. Undergroud celler corridors makes is possible to transport patients from one pavillon to another.

Hospital/museum in Barcelona.  Interesting architecture, beautiful stained glass windows.  Younger kids would probably get bored; people with mobility issues would have problems - area is spread out with lots of stairs.

Continue past the Sagrada Familia - sorry about the spelling - and continue half a mile til you get to this old medical hospital. Quite unbelievable beauty and art deco throughout. Definitely worth a visit
The light show at night is something to behold. Wish I had pictures but I only took video. Worth the trip in our opinion.

Visited here as third trip to Barcelona and had seen the well-known Modernista buildings.  It is absolutely stunning!  Huge, beautiful and a fascinating museum about the history of the hospital.  Only a short walk from the Sagrada Família and, in my opinion, a more worthwhile destination.
This was a beautiful surprise. Audio guide didn’t work too well but regardless there is so much to just look at visually.

Stumbled across this gem. Mosaics galore and a peaceful and calm place. Tricky to get around but you are free to wander. The tunnels, turrets and tremendous outlooks. Make sure you watch the video in the round room. It really helps.
The Hospital Sant Pau is almost an unknown tourist destination in Barcelona, but situated just 5 blocks from Sagrada Familia Basilica, it should be a "Must See" site
It is really a nice place to visit, but entering basically a part of nice garden and main building there is no much can be visited.

Our last day in Barcelona was a Sunday and admission to Recinte Modernista de Sant Pau, a beautiful complex of Modernist buildings designed by Lluis Domenech I Montaner, was free. The complex, built between 1901 and 1930, served as a fully functioning hospital until June 2009, when it began to be restored for use as a museum and cultural center. The Metro delivered us to the modern Hospital de Sant Pau, and from there it was a rather long but fortunately downhill walk to the Modernist complex. The buildings were even more beautiful than we had anticipated and the displays of medical equipment and explanations of treatment practices were interesting. We were so happy to be able to visit this unexpected treasure.

I visited sant pau on 11 am tour guide for 20 euro, this place is beautiful, I forgot guide name but he was very nice and gave all the answers along with tour, from image you can't believe it was hospital with beautiful concept

In contrast to extremely excellent reviews, there are some bad reviews about this place. Therefore, my family went to the site and asked a staff member which building we were allowed to visit. She pointed at all the buildings (around nine?) we could enter and told my family the closing time was at 5:00pm. When I checked the time, it was already over 2:00pm, so we rushed to buy our tickets.
As we entered, beautiful buildings and trees welcomed us. However, Only three buildings were for tourists, and when we entered one building the interior was dilapidated. 
Exteriors of each building is absolutely beautiful, but there is not much to see the history of the old hospital. Almost nothing.
We were extremely disappointed at limited accesses tourists had. 
Garden???? There were beautiful orange trees and some wild flowers. If you call it a garden, I guess it is different from what people call a garden in the United States.

I was blown away by this visit. Fascinating story, along with beautiful buildings and information about the past made it one of my favourite activities in Barcelona. Stunning layout and the tours seemed very good although I did self-guided due to time restraints. Information booklet was handy for this and there was lots of additional information at each point of interest. Well worth a visit, especially walking up from Sagrada Familia along the Avinguda Gaudí.
Beautiful architecture with high arches, colorful and gorgeous. Works great and ancient. It took us over 2 hours to visit this place.
Spectacular modernist building very close to Sagrada Familia. It is a hidden gem and a must do in Barcelona. Inside you feel the silence and can enjoy the beautiful buildings. I really loved it.

St Pau is trully spectacular and a must visit in Barcelona. The site seems to be very well looked after and the visit was very pleasant as it was not crowded at all. 
It was way larger than I thought but it can be visited in about an hour.
Not only functional for the beginning of the 20th Century Hospital but very impressive in its architecture.

The buildings of this hospital at truly wonderful and you can easily understand why this is a Unesco world heritage site. This used to be a functioning hospital until 2009 when the new Sant Pau hospital opened next door.
I was extremely fortunate to be shown round by the hospital's former medical director and also a group of doctors that used to work in this building. It is unbelievable that this was functioning as a hospital until 2009. The medical care they were providing was not just low level support. The doctors that showed me round are of international standard and this place was of the standard of most European hospitals. For example they used to do bone marrow transplants here and the first one ever carried out in Spain took place here.

There are so many facets to this spectacular ‘masterpiece’. The strong use of brick and coloured and glazed tiles used is a relatively common feature seen around Barcelona. But this site was magnificent and it almost defies belief that one man could have such a vision for not only the architectural style but the conceptual design and layout of a trail blazing hospital.  Never to be missed. Easy to get to on the metro.

5 STARS (exterior visual elements)  We only viewed the exterior architectural elements.
We took a taxi from Park Guell to St Paul Hospital to take exterior photos.  If we had more time, I would have paid the admission to see the inside.  Just the free exterior photos create a great memory, however, and you can easily and leisurely continue to walk the 4 or 5 blocks to the Sagrada Familia from the hospital.  This is an awesome architectural achievement, especially since this was built as a public hospital until 2014.  The origins of the hospital date back to 1401.

...one must experience in Barcelona. The former hospital is just amazingly beautiful. The buildings themselves but also the insides...just wow. In parts, you’ll feel like in an “American Horror Story” episode (season 2)...
My 8 year old daughter loves this place and listened to all the  audio guide..a must see in Barcelona. The roof tops are all amazing.
is what I am reviewing- excellent, great tour and music a real highlight when in Barcelona   get your tickets ahead of time   very worhtwhile
An amazing visit to this extraordinary jewel of modernist architecture that was a working hospital until only a few years ago.  Do mot miss the numerous mosaics, glasswork, lamps, and the tunnels.

I LOVED this place!  If you love beauty, Art Nouveau, and design excellence, you will, too!  First off, DO get the audioguide to fully appreciate this marvellous place.   It was designed by the brilliant architect, Lluis Domenech i Montaner, who was a teacher of Gaudi's, and was created as a hospital for the poor.  The architect believed in the natural healing power of beauty and nature and wanted to create a place where the poor could recuperate and heal while in the midst of nature, beauty, and light.  He designed pavilions that were dedicated to specific medical purposes e.g. maternity, non-contagious diseases, etc., and they were all connected by underground tunnels.  Revolutionary!

There were very few people on the day we went and this was a breath of fresh air because we could take pictures of the stunning buildings without having heads in every photo.  :-D  The hospital is a secret treasure and underrated gem.  It is a UNESCO world heritage site but not many have discovered it.  Once you're inside, the place just takes your breath away!  I loved loved loved it and it was a highlight of our stay in Barcelona.  We sacrificed seeing Park Guell to see this place and never repented the decision.  It is totally worth the time and money to see it.
This was a brilliant visit. The hospital is being restored to perfection and with great sensitivity. The ceilings are among the most beautiful I've ever seen and I can't forget the sight of them!

There are many Gaudi like touches in this what was once a hospital that believed in combining green space with healing. There are sculptures and mosaics scattered throughout the complex. Need to see with an audio guide or a private guide to get the most benefit from this UNESCO World Heritage Site.

overshadowed by the sagrada (and literally 10 minute walk north) , the hospital de sant pau is truly magnificent . the architecture , grounds and excellent audio guide, made this the number one attraction in barcelona for me. for some reason , not as many people know about this world unesco site , so very  little crowds. highly recommend

As a healthcare worker, I loved visiting this place. You can wander through the old hospital and image what it was like to be a patient here in the past.  Restoration is still underway but you can walk through the underground tunnels, visit some of the old wards and walk through the admin building.  The grounds are beautiful and the buildings are quite interesting.  Enjoy!
We spent a morning enjoying the architechture and the historical explanations. Very well restored monument to Art Noueau

This is a bit of a hidden gem, especially being so near to the Sagrada Familia. No booking required and we walked into a feast of art nouveau/deco buildings, as well as the history sitting alongside the Sagrada Familia down the street. The architecture is a joy to see, including lovely gloss fired bricks, tiles on the rooves and inside. Definitely not to be missed.

Being there transports you to a place that’s unbelievable 
How a hospital at that time could have being so modern luxurious and beautiful 
The place it’s amazing find miss it 
Enjoy

Missed this place on my first visit to Barcelona, but so glad I visited this time. The buildings and rooms were beautiful, especially when it's sunny. It's away from the tourist crowds. It's interesting picturing this place as a functional hospital just a few years ago.
Gorgeous tile work in several buildings of what used to be a hospital.  This sight is a hidden gem that is not overcrowded like so many of the sights in Barcelona.

A amazing collection of buildings that provides an in-depth look at a modernista architect other than Gaudi (less florid but more subtle detailing and generally more practical). The detailing is sensational, plus introduces the philosophy of beautiful spaces being healing for the sick (one building is partially set up as a ward of the hospital as it originally was) - light, airy and decorated, rather than the grim greyness of previous hospital spaces.  It is connected by a road directly to Sagrada Familia (20 minute walk) so combining the two is convenient.
The place looks surprisingly so new. I had underestimated this place but the experience was much better than expected. The place is huge.
We rushed up the hill on our last day based on reviews - and we were only sorry we hadn't saved more time to walk around the grounds.  Well worth the price and the experience....

As everyone who goes there knows, it's not crowded, no pre-bought tickets necessary and the audio guide is a must. Otherwise you'd never understand the complicated architecture and history of health care in those times

This former hospital complex is not far from the more famous la Sagrada Familia, and can be reached via a pleasant pedestrian walkway from the cathedral. Designed by Gaudi's less famous but equally influential architect Montaner, the hospital was built specifically to help sick people recover more quickly by putting them in beautiful surroundings, full of colorful tiles and ceramics, fantastic statuary, and lush gardens. It wasn't crowded when we visited, and provided a welcome respite from the crowds at La Sagrada Familia and Barcelona in general.

When my wife said we have to get off the Hop on Bus at this site, I said why? I didn’t realize what we were about to see. Sant Pau is a total complex of buildings, not just one building. This former hospital complex is beautiful. It was redone into a modern version of the former working hospital. You can easily spend a half a day viewing the various buildings and architecture. This is a hidden treasure in Barcelona that is usually not mentioned on most tours.

This previous hospital implemented some of the major advances of medicine during the days before bacterial and viral infections were well understood.  The Art Nouveau architecture lifts the spirit and the fresh-air in the gardens lifts life.  Walk the white-tiled underground tunnels that link the buildings and visit the museum displays before settling down for a coffee and visiting the excellent gift shop,  great selection, good value.

Decided to visit here as we couldn’t get tickets for the Sagrida and we were not disappointed. What a beautiful place and unbelievable to think it was a Hospital as it’s an architectural masterpiece. Should definitely be on your to do list

We decided to visit this site based on Trip Advisor recommendations and it was definitely worth the visit.  The architecture is stunning.  It is a closed hospital complex that has beautiful buildings and an underground tunnel system.  The interior displays are medical related so if you’re not into that you can simple skip them and concentrate on the buildings themselves and grounds.  There is not much in this area so I would suggest visiting either before or after going to La Sagrada.  There is a metro stop in front of the Basilica and I believe it’s only 1 metro stop to Recinete or you can walk.
You must see it. Beatufully decorated buildings( different wards of hospital) conected by underground corridors.

An expansive and stunning structure of a hospital complex of global size and significance conceived 600 years ago with a building dedicated to treating a particular ailment of line of treatment which turns into an amazing experience of this grand idea taking place 6 centuries ago.

we were told about this hospital complex by a friend who worked there for 30 years.  It is not on the “must do” list for Barcelona, but we found it to be an exquisite example of Modernism.  The campus has symmetrical buildings that give the place a sense of harmony.  We toured on our own,  many buildings are not open to visitors.  But enough to give a sense of the place and the grounds are likewise lovely. Definitely worth a visit.  We had a Barcelona card and this was on it.

Have visited today, very few people around. Payed 10.50 for youngsters (up to 29 years) and 15€ for adult. 
We got a map of building which we are able to go look at and it was about half of the buildings which were already beautifully reconstructed. 
It took us tops 90 mins to go through the area

A beautiful campus of a former hospital that has been preserved.  Many modernist buildings, and you can go in most of them. There are also surreal tunnels that you can go in that connect the buildings.  Designed by Catalonia's often overshadowed architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner.  Spend an enjoyable hour or two here.

If the weather is pleasant you must visit this converted hospital just blocks away from the crowds at the cathedral. This is not where the masses go which makes it even more of a delight to visit. 

A complex encompassing several acres and many buildings connected by tunnels or accessible from above, follow the suggested tour route. If any of the roofs are open, usually accidentally as during our visit, make sure you go up as the complex is better viewed from above. 

They have recreated the environment from when this was a practicing hospital in a number of locations, helping to bring the novelty of this campus into focus. A super way to spend a couple of hours while in the city, easily accessed and not overwhelmed as the cathedral. Cheers!
We did not go into the hospital, but the outside architecture is definitely worth a stop.  Very symetrical, beauitufl adorned, and creative in design.

After our mid-day visit to Sagrada Familia, we  visited the Sant Pau Art Nouveau site – an easy walk of about 3 blocks from Sagrada Familia, up a pedestrian street. Sant Pau is a renovated hospital site of about 9 buildings, which as they advertize are “jewels”. Bring your best camera; weather permitting, you won’t believe the photo ops.

Our fabulous concierge suggested a visit here. What a tranquil gem in the bustling heat of Barcelona. An inspirational space for the care of the sick and now a beautiful monument to it. Both my daughter & I enjoyed the cool highly decorative buildings and gardens. 
Highly recommend as a gem off the tourist path 😊
As the rest of Barcelona, the Receinte Modernista is a magnificent building with incredible architecture. It is worth to pay a visit!

Having stayed in Barcelona previously and visited most of the well known sites, we saw an advertisement for the Hospital and decided to visit, and we are very glad we did.  Very short walking distance from the Metro, the site was not crowded and did not have to queue. We opted for the guided tour, in English, starting at 11am, which was very informative, a comfortable pace and lasted just over the hour.  We were then free to roam around the site at will revisiting those areas seen on the guided tour.  We definitely recommend a visit, it was certainly worthwhile and would happily return for another visit as and when we travel to Barcelona again.

Walking distance from Sagrada and a highlight of Barcelona for us. We arrived at 5pm - gorgeous light on the buildings and hardly any tourists - less than 20. Great to get away from the crowds. Beautiful former hospital designed by contemporary of Gaudí. Well worth the visit.

This beautiful place is a five minute walk from Sagrada Família. It was used as a hospital until 2009. We paid £17 for an Adult entrance ticket which included the guide. The guide was excellent and required. You need the guide because the thought behind the decor and setting is explained, along with how the patients benefited and it’s very interesting. Of course Gaudí had some input!!
This site is a revelation, great architecture and history behind the buildings. A must visit for any traveller to Barcelona.

Sant Pau Art nouveau hospital was the highlight of our visit in the city. The fantastic Gaudi buildings are not to be missed, but the high entrance fees and masses of people is a challenge. At San Pau it is peaceful and there are very few tourists. The complex is not fully restored yet, but the lovely gardens and buildings is amazing. A number of wards and rooms are open and the outsides of the buildings are beautiful. The entrance fee is very reasonable and it is on the hop on bus route and within walking distance from the Sagrada.

So glad we booked a tour with Context and was able to see this beautiful, heartwarming campus.  My favorite part was learning how much detail and thought they put into the design around making sure the patient was as comfortable as possible and providing natural sunlight to speed up the recovery process/improve mental health during tough times.  MUST SEE!!!!
This is building is absolutely gorgeous. On Tuesdays it is possible to visit it for free until 2:30pm.

Had a great visit here after a short walk from La Sagrada Familia.  Sant Pau is a wonderful, beautiful (and, miraculously, lightly visited) complex that displays both gorgeous architecture and an amazing sensitivity to the needs of the ill that is sorely lacking in this high tech age.   Highly recommended.

We arrived late to this location and we a bit concerned. An hour was very adequate to explore the grounds and architecture of this abandon hospital. If you have time, the interesting tile work and many extra building details merit a visit.

This is a little-known (at least to Americans) structure - or complex of buildings - that I recommend for any student of art or architecture. The good doctor's vision of health care that centers the patients proves that beauty can be combined with efficiency. The turrets and towers and tiles, all by Lluis Domenich I Montaner, are just as amazing as Gaudi's, and we are so lucky this place is now renovated. It is the LARGEST ART NOUVEAU structure in Europe, and I guess that makes it the largest in the world.
Very well restored, most modern hospital in the world when it opened, largest Modernista ensemble in the world, a must see.

It's not crowded and its wonderful. A former hospital complex designed by Lluis Domenech i Montaner in 1902. Now a UNESCO World Heritage site. The design of the 12 jewel box buildings has been described as Moorish-inspired or alternatively as gothic revival. No doubt a bit of both.

Stunning architecture, fantastic tour guides and so far a relatively unknown tourist attraction very close to Plaça de  la Sagrada Família. We visited in September when Barcelona is still full of tourists and had a leisurely visit with tour guide. She was very helpful and informative. Totally recommend this beautiful place.

Avoid the crowds of the Gaudi sites and visit Sant Pau Recinte Modernista. A definitive argument against flat roofs! So many amazing architectural details. Well worth a visit. Easy to see why it got UNESCO World Heritage status. From a different era in health care - a garden city for nursing the sick. Sant Pau was built in a period of considerable change and economic expansion in Barcelona.

This was one of the places I was looking forward to most but I left with mixed feelings. On the one hand the buildings are stunning and it's such an interesting historical and medical concept. On the other hand however most of the buildings can't be entered and you can see everything in 30 mins. There is very little to actually explore in terms of interiors and I'm not sure whether it would be worth €12 admission in hindsight. Luckily we went during La Merce festival 24 sep and got in completely free - so definitely lookout for holiday dates when the place has open doors!
Good place to walk after breakfast or lunch. Very calm and peaceful. Not crowded and we were able to enjoy walking around with a great center view of La Sagrada Familia.

Close to the St Pau Metro station (Line 5) is this wonderful collection of art nouveau buildings which comprise an old hospital plus various pavilions.It is a celebration of Cataln Modernista architecture as well as a museum.
It is all totally unspoilt even though it adjoins a modern hospital.
Well worth a visit.
I can't believe this used to be a hospital. It is more like a palace. The tile work and mosaics were amazing. Highly recommended

Like others have said - this place is simply not worth the entrance fee. €30 for two of us to do a self guided tour. It started off well enough inside with us being told to 'follow the arrows' - once outside however there was a complete lack of arrows or any other signage to say where to go. Most of the buildings were closed off to the public and those which were open had many rooms roped of. 
It's a real pity - we had looked forward to visiting for months but ultimately it just left a €30 bad taste in our mouths.
We have never seen such a gorgeous hospital. What a cultural shift, to purposely design a gorgeous building and grounds to improve the health and experience of the sick. Highly recommend going here.

We visited one morning in glorious sunshine. the buildings were of impressive architecture and the history as a hospital was well explained. The overall impression was of a beautiful peaceful place to spend a few hours

Only up the road from Sagrada Familia but very few visitors compared to the crowds around the Sagrada. It was a peaceful and restful haven, the architect certainly knew what he was doing to provide a wonderfully beautiful place to recover for the hospital patients. A definite place to visit if you appreciate brightly decorated rooms. Also the information about the hospital’s history and the philosophy of the architect.

Buildings are intricately design.

Large complex with many buildings to tour. 

It is quite under rated for what it has to offer.

This Unesco site is an amazing hospital complex built in the Modernisme style and while not Gaudi, should be on everyone's Barcelona itinerary. The tile work and design of the buildings in a beautiful garden setting is awesome and beautiful. You get a sense of this from walking around the outside but it is well worth the €15 admission ticket. The hospital history is very interesting in it's own right apart from the architectural paradise! It is a short ride on the subway and  so very easy to get to. Allow a couple of hours to enjoy this hidden gem. It wasn't busy when we visited in the morning in late August.
Definitively not to be missed

Nice if you have few hours to spend.
I would not come just for it, but when in the area come and visit.
If you are standing in front of the hospital you can not imagine how big and beautiful it is inside. Everyone would be happy to go into this hospital. It was such a great visit!

I have a new favorite Catalan architect.  Gaudí is more well known to the average tourist, but Lluís Domènech i Montaner doesn’t disappoint.  I missed it during my first visit to Barcelona, so glad I got to see it on the second round.
Really worth a visit. Such an amazing complex. Spent about 2 hours here. Walking distance from Sagrada Familia.
The place is not so popular among the tourists so you have not to wait in lines. The garden inside of the complex is very beautiful. I like the architecture so much!

Lluís Domènech i Montaner designed a complex of individual pavillions with the genius thoughts that each maladie should be treated specifically to avoid any cross contamination, provide the needs for each group of patients and to be full of natural light and fresh air. We wish contemporary healing centers had the same design and attitude.
We walked from Sagrada Famila to Hospital San Pau. Since the line at Sagrada familia was so long we skipped it. San Paul was not as crowded and well worth a visit.
Barcelona is packed with amazing architecture. Im sure if the sagrada familia wasnt just up the road from this, it would be more of a famous landmark. Its another incredible piece of architecture.

Most visitors know all about the work of Gaudi and will visit his works but have you heard of Lluís Domènech i Montaner? Well I hadn't until we visited Sant Pau and it's the most gorgeous place.

The site is large and an audio guide is the best way to make sure that you don't miss the marvels here. Not all of it has been fully restored and the contrast between the areas is shocking.

Sant Pau was a hospital and the architect believed that the patients could recover more quickly in beautiful surroundings and what beauty there is here.

Add it to you list of must sees.
Seeing this building it is hard to believe that it is a hospital. The building and grounds are beautiful and well worth the extra walk to visit.

Spectacular - don’t miss!!
The Recinte Modernista de Sant Pau Barcelona
The Recinte Modernista de Sant Pau (former Hospital de Sant Pau) is also on the UNESCO World Heritage List. It represents the hospital complex that was in part designed by Gaudi and functioned as hospital from the 1930s to the end of the millennium when the medical care was moved out to a modern replacement. 
What remained was a stunning complex of beautiful and coloerful architecture, just in walking distance North East of the Sagrada Familia, is definitely worth visiting – with much less hassle and without need to make any reservations. 

(Originally posted by me on yelp)
Very nice place in Barcelona without a lot of tourists !! It’s like Parc Güell but empty ! You can take a drink or eat at the end perfect !

We absolutely loved our visit here.  One of the best things we did in our whole trip.  Gorgeous buildings, really well-designed self-guided tour through these incredible buildings, and not at all crowded.  The photos and displays give you an amazing sense of the history of medicine, as well as the history of Barcelona as a city, all in a beautiful and serene setting both indoors and out.  Don't miss it!!!

Santa Pau Art Nouveau site far surpassed any other place I visited in Barcelona.  This complex of buildings was constructed in the early 20th century as a hospital.  I have never seen such a wonderful place.  The architect took great care to make the environment relaxing and comforting for patients with beautifully ornate tiles on the walls and ceilings of rooms and wards.  Buildings are linked by a garden on the ground level and tunnels beneath the ground.
I wasn't aware of this gems lying in the city but i give it a try and dicover a magnificeient site empty of tourists.

Great architecture. Visit the different pavillions with photos of the historiy of building  and medicine. 
Not well known attraction but Unesco Hermitage,  but certainly worth a  visit, not far from Sagrada familia

A local friend recommended a visit to this place and it was my favorite tour in Barcelona. The audio guide gives a great explanation of the history of the grounds, the vision for this public hospital and the amazing architecture. I have a new appreciation for “hospital green”! 
Plan to spend a few hours here. It is not far from the Sagrada Familia and could be done in the same day.
It should be ranked much higher.  Beautiful buildings, not a building but a Hugh complex, designed for hospital from start with beauty as therapeutical power in mind.

I feel so lucky that my tour of the Sagrada Família started here! It really gave me a sense of how this whole area of Barcelona started. This should be on everyone’s visit. It is crazy that that are 27 reviews for this and over 150,000 for Sagrada Família. They are like 5-6 blocks away from each other and face each other on avenida Gaudi. This hospital is beautiful! It was my introduction to Lluis Domènech i Montaner. His attention to detail, love of nature, mosaics, stained glass and just everything were amazing! It is no wonder this hospital had the quickest healing rate. People were being treated in a work of art, a masterpiece! Surrounded by well thought out beauty everywhere!  You really have to see it to believe it! If it was not on your list, add it. It really is amazing! Wouldn’t it be great if hospitals looked like this today?

It is 20min walk from Alfons X metro station, I visited on the way back from Parc Guell (there are 2 closer stations) , you could go to both on the same day if your schedule allows. A 1.5 hrs should do but the architecture and details are amazing, a must see if you have not seen. Barcelona has too many things to see in a couple of days it deserves time to explore.

The hospital comprises a wonderful collection of buildings, beautifully laid out and with many amazing architectural and decorative features. I visited on the 1st Sunday of July, and was delighted to discover that admission is free on the 1st Sunday of each month, but it would have been well worth the admission price anyway. People were dancing in the central area of the hospital grounds and there was a lovely party-like atmosphere. There are informative and interesting displays about the history of the hospital and its role in medical developments in Barcelona. Not to be missed. It's unlike any other hospitaI I have ever seen, and was in use as a hospital until relatively recently.

We visited on our last day in Barcelona.  I had read about it on Trip Advisor, and a fellow tour member had visited 2 days earlier.  It was a hospital which was built from 1902 to 1930.  The beauty of the buildings and their surroundings are so impressive.  The tile work, the mosaics, the angels and the gardens - all part of a hospital.  They were meant to give hope and comfort to patients and they now amaze visitors to the landmark.  It is a must-see in Barcelona.

You have to see it. It is amazing how the buildings connect through underground pathways. A beautiful place to relax. I can see that the environment made the patients feel better. Hard to believe that so much money and effort was spent to provide public healthcare. There are so many details (windows, columns, tiles etc.) you will not get tired of exploring.

Some places are intended to impress and some impress by their intent.  Face it, the Sagrada Familia is monumental - large and overwhelming but every inch of it is there to impress and awe.  It is intentional ostentatious and succeeds marvelously.  You should go and you will be blown away.

Not far away, however is the Hospital Sant Pau which is the largest modernistic architectural site in the world.  I found complex and self guided tour  far more impressive than the Sagrada.  The hospital is a beautiful campus built specifically to provide the most advanced medical care for needy patients.  How wonderful is that? This beautiful facility with stately buildings, sculptures and gardens was built expressly to take care of the poor not the rich. That is amazing. And every part of it was built to be thoughtful and scientific but also comforting for the patients.  One need only compare it to Bellevue in New York to understand how advanced and humane this hospital was.

Be sure to get the audio guide when you come, because you will miss so much of the rich history and culture otherwise.  The guide fills you in on the background and points out all the rich details that you would not notice.

The other advantage to Hospital Sant Pau is that it is relatively undiscovered so there are no long lines, crowds or pressure to move through the exhibits.  You can spend as much time as you want.  We did not need reservation for tickets and you should be able to get in at no charge if you have a Barcelona Card.

By all means put this on your list.

We enjoyed walking through here on the freebie day, but I don't think I'd pay to get in.  The courtyard area is pretty, there are a few pretty buildings as well.  If you enjoy history you would spend more time here and enjoy it more.  If you just want photos you will spend 20-30 minutes walking around.

Seriously, this place is a must see. Also, give yourself time to soak in the information and walk around. Friends told us about this place they were told was great but didn’t yet manage to see it.. one of those places that they defo should go see, what a hidden gem. La Sagrada Família probably takes the limelight but this place isn’t far away (under 10 min walk away). The person who built it? Oh, only Gaudi’s mentor. It might be 19 euro with audioguide but it’s worth every penny. Beautiful concept, if ONLY public hospitals could have been like this and better.....

Want to see one of Barcelona's most beautiful buildings without the crowds?  Check out the Hospital de Sant Pau by architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner.  He did the famous Palau de la Musica too.  This place is astounding for the combination of function and beauty.  Get the audio tour and be prepared to be awed!  Not only did this place provide clean, airy, beautiful surroundings for patients at the beginning of the 20th Century, it functioned as a hospital until 2009 when the new one was completed.  This complex of buildings has such visionary touches as some of the first 'accessible ramps' for getting in the doors (due to the slope of the hill). And the ceiling of the administration building stopped us in our tracks.  The tile work alone is worth the price of admission.  It is located within sight of the Sagrada Familia so if you are visiting the church, make time to come see this beauty and then have lunch on the avenue between the two.  A perfect day!

This gem was quite a treat to see. Hidden away in a non-description neighborhood go see the old Hospital of Sant Pau, there you will find this beautiful set of building called Recinte Moderniste.  The architect was Domenech y Montaner. Each building is more beautiful than the next. Be sure to visit the inside, they gorgeous tile work . The street leading up to it is Avenida de Gaudí which leads you straight to Sagrada Familia.
Beautiful and colorful ceramic decoration on the walls and ceilings. Buildings from fairy tales! Not to miss!
This is amazing. Really beautiful and also quite tranquil. The highlight of my trip. Probably not for everyone, but interesting medical and architectural history. Beautifully restored.

This complex of buildings was designed by Lluís Domènech i Montaner and untill 2009, it was a hospital. That year it was declared a UNESCO monument and became a visiting attraction. 
I highly recommend this as it is somehow not that commercial and a bit off the beaten track. It was not crowded at all and it is a hidden gem. The buildings are breathtaking and the garden has a lot of beautiful flowers. You have to take the guided tour from their website. It was worth the visit.

Domenech I Montaner designed this as a hodpity No longer used as such. Now a tourist destination. A riot of art nouveau and ceramic tiles.

Note the closing time and minimum your time means they won’t allow admission after 14.00

Wandering around a former hospital may not sound like a great time but rest assured that this former hospital is such an architectural gem that it is time well spent. The buildings are beautiful and wandering around the center quite illuminating. As others have noted, most of the buildings are closed but the four or five that we were permitted to enter were beautiful. Also included are extensive informational placards that explain the history of this former hospital.

We did the audio guide visit and this place is amazing. We did a full-day Gaudí tour the day before, and then visited this UNESCO world heritage site the next day, which was designed by Gaudí’s mentor (who also did the Palau de Música downtown). We loved seeing the tile work on the building exteriors. 1-2 hours is fine for this visit.

If you are interested in architecture, and want a feel for the ethos of the city, add this to your agenda! The buildings are beautiful and site is quite peaceful - on a June afternoon, it was by no means crowded. We got the audio guide, as we missed the guided tour for the day, and I highly recommend it - it was informative, providing interesting images and context.  The exhibition elements within the site were interesting and informative as well, providing great detail on the history and development of the institution, and the life and work of the architect, using a nice blend of historic objects, text, and interactives -  providing a ton of information without being overwhelming, if you just wanted to skim through. We left far more informed about the urban development of Barcelona,  the city's approach to the turn-of the 20th century trend of edifying the working classes through improvements to the urban landscape, and the Catalan art nouveau style.

This place was recommended by our friend and it was definitely a place you don't want to miss. Beautiful and less crowded compare to other Barcelona attractions. We wanted to rent audio guide but the staff at ticket desk told us there are signs in English which we can read. Indeed there are - for all places marked on the map. There were also friendly staff standing in front of buildings to show us where to go next when we seemed lost.

We had just visited La Sagrada Familia and decided to walk down the street to Sant Pau on the recommendation of our taxi driver.  We looked at it and thought why pay 10 euros for this site not realizing that it consists of many buildings and has beautiful grounds.  Glad we decided to enter and take the audioguide.  Quite a set of art nouveau buildings which served as a hospital until 2009.  A pleasant way to spend some time away from the hustle and bustle of Barcelona.

A wonderful building with a lot of history, for me personally it is much more impressive than La Sagrada, just because it has been used for centuries with a good reason. Congrats for Barcelona for keeping this lovely monument, highly recommended

It is a fascinating, as the other reviews say, but once I got through the entrance building and started going from hall to hall in the main courtyard, I found that most of them were not accessible. Perhaps they are being renovated. Frankly, I felt ripped off
Incredible architecture and gardens. Each pavilion has something great to offer and walking through the gardens is both relaxing and inviting.

Just up the Av de Gaudi from Sagrada Familia is this spectacular peaceful haven where you can relax away from the crowds at the Sagrada. It is an old art nouveau hospital that has been refurbished.  On arrival the awesome central facade with a huge clock tower greets you.  Inside the 26 rooms (not all were open) have beautiful ceilings and you get a history of the hospital.  There is an immaculate ward laid out as if it is awaiting new patients.  There are displays of old medical equipment including an old x-ray machine, operating implements and even an original Boots the Chemist inhaler.  There are sculptures and mosaic panels and colourful ceramic roof tiles.  The grounds are well laid out with plants, citrus trees and shady trees to sit under and relax.

My wife and I visited San Pau during a recent visit to Barcelona. We dropped off there from the hop-on-hop-off bus tour that stopped just outside.
It is a former hospital and is probalby the best example of the 'modernisa' architecture in the city. 
Fabulous architecture in iteresting displays.
Highly recommented.

The beauty of this former hospital has to be seen to be believed. Catalan modernism and neo gothic masterpiece by Lluís Domènech i Montaner is well presented with plenty of English language translations and a great audio guide. Well thought out and administered. 

The architecture and decoration will blow you away. Well worth the trip.

worth seeing even if it's not on every list

appreciate the architecture and go before the crowds to appreciate it

This hospital is several hundred years old. It is a group of about 20 buildings. Each building was for a specific specialty.  The architecture is beautiful and colorful.  Very easy to walk around from one building to another.  Definitely an attraction worth seeing.

We hadn't heard of this old hospital until we visited Barcelona.
However, it turned out to be one of the highlights of our visit (coming second only to the interior of the Sagrada Familia).
Don't miss it. 
Fascinating and beautiful.

This is a very old hospital complex not far from the La Rambla.  It is in the old section of town and can be alittle smelly in certain places.  This is where Gaudi was taken after being struck by a street car and later died.  It now has a large Library for students.  The best thing is El Jardin, a small garden cafe which is great for wine and tapas.

Incredible complex of a former hospital, just up the street from Sagrada Familia. We almost missed out on the inside, but decided to go inside. So glad we did, because as lovely as the facade is, the rest is indescribable. An entire village of modernist hospital buildings built by Gaudi’s architecture professor, it was a case of a genius teaching genius. A UNESCO site, and for good reason. Not cheap, but you are supporting a meticulously restored masterpiece. Excellent audio guide. Give yourself at least 90 minutes to poke around everywhere and watch the movies.

My wife and I had a little extra time in Barcelona and decided to check out this interesting site. We were so glad we took the trouble to see it. Although not designed by Gaudi it is so beautiful. The main building of this old hospital is magnificent as are the surrounding buildings. If you have the time, go see Recinte Modernista!

These are two of the finest contributions to Barcelona's architecture by the Catalan art nouveau architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner. The Palau de la Música Catalana is an exuberant steel-framed structure full of light and space, and decorated by many of the leading designers of the day. The Hospital de Sant Pau is equally bold in its design and decoration, while at the same time perfectly adapted to the needs of the sick.

I had not been to Barcelona for a few years and I was therefore delighted to find this historic hospital complex, which only opened to the public a few years ago.  For anyone interested in architecture, art and the design of hospitals, this must not be missed, especially as it is within walking distance of the Sagrada Familia, which you can see from the first floor windows of the administration building. 

The old Sant Pau hospital goes back to the 15th century but was completely rebuilt between 1901 and 1930 by the Catalan architect Lluis Domenech I Montaner (not as well known as Gaudi).  The interiors of the wards, one of which has been recreated, were quite functional - following similar planning guidelines to hospitals here at the time, but one of the tricks was that there was a series of wide tunnels underneath for beds, trolleys etc, so the buildings are separated and the grounds are well-landscaped, for patients to enjoy.  The best artists of the time were employed for the decoration of the buildings and of the interiors of the main administrative building, which are beautiful examples of architecture and art at the time. .  

The hospital was in use until 2009, and has been replaced with a new modern one a short distance away which has a new research building and the first Maggie's Cancer Centre outside of the UK.  The site has been opened since 2014 as a museum and cultural centre, after extensive renovation with some of the buildings rented out to related organisations, including Barcelona University and one of the 'waiting-to-be-restored' wards is also open to see.  There are excellent exhibitions at the beginning and, later, within the tunnels, that give the history of the hospital, its architecture and its artists. 

Also, don't miss the church just round the corner, which is open and still in use.

Highly recommend this architectural gem, in Barcelona.  Multiple buildings are open for you to walk through with detailed information of the history of medicine in Barcelona and the architectural highlights of an important era of medical care in the city.  Not too far from Sagrada Familia.

A beautiful example of architect Domanech i Montaner. The guidebooks do not promote this site as a “top” attraction perhaps because it is not in the city center and a little off the beaten path. We are adventurous and took a bus. Got slightly lost but a very nice neighborhood. We are grateful that a friend encouraged us to visit. It is not crowded and the gift shop is really nice. Quite a few buildings are under restoration from within but there is much to see. Allow 1.5 - 2 hours.

The buildings and grounds here are beautiful. We had looked at previous reviews and totally agree that it’s definitely a place to visit if you’re in Barcelona.
It’s spotlessly clean both inside and out. The buildings are ornate and the displays allow you to get a real feel of how things were all those years ago. The grounds have seats around where you can sit to take in the beauty of the place. We paid €14 each for a self guided tour. You need to allow yourself about 1 1/2 hours to look around. 
Please click below if you found this review helpful - thank you

I almost hate to review this place as it is a hidden gems without large crowds. If you like architecture at all, you must go here. It's beautiful and an amazing concept of a hospital that was well before it's time. I could spend hours just wondering and sitting in the space. We lucked out and went on day that was free to the public but missed getting an audioguide. We were able to enjoy and learn about the history without but would like to go back someday an learn more.

Visited this place after seeing it on my bus tour. Looked very interesting. 
We entered to be ignored by every member of staff. 
Wasn’t quite sure where to buy tickets which I worked out in the end. Got to the correct desk but was continued to be ignore by 5 members of staff. 
The only guy that seemed half interested was the guy who checked the tickets & helped me with my audio guide. 

The place itself is great & lots of information on the audio guide. 
Would recommend a visit but the staff really need to shape up if they want to compete with the other attractions in Barcelona.
This is a must see that most tourists miss.  It is an art nouveau gem.  From Sagrada Familia, walk up Ave Gaudi about a mile and you will arrive. You can also take the metro.
Complex of buildings with very interesting architecture in the Eixample district of Barcelona, near Sagrada Familia. Definitely worth seeing.

We passed Sant Pau on a city sightseeing bus tour and had to go and have a look.

In a city full of the works of Gaudi, this one isn't, but don't let that put you off because the buildings and interiors are fantastic.

The administration building is just like a cathedral with a towering spire outside and a towering domed ceiling inside.

Some of the buildings are still being restored, so don't expect perfection and some of the buildings aren't open to the public - some are still actually part of the modern hospital - but to be honest, this adds to the experience for me.

Very highly recommended!
Taken by some friends on the guided tour. Really interesting and amazing place. Go if you town its really worth it

I loved this - not as crowded as Gaudi houses 
It’s stunning and the administration building tiled domed pink roof will blow you away 
Do not miss

This place is beautiful, and especially enchanting if you’re a little tired of seeing only Gaudi’s works in the city (as most tourists do). Imo, there are 3 reasons why this is more impressive than the nearby Park Guell: 

The original complex of 12+ buildings are incredibly well preserved and beautiful to begin with. Even though many are used as offices today, their external facades can still be appreciated up close. 

The admission fee is the same as the Park, and there are far less people here! This place also tastefully uses technology (videos, interviews, touchscreen exhibitions) to add to your overall understanding and experience, unlike the Park.

This hospital has centuries of history, and wasn’t just an ex-estate of some rich benefactor. Medicinal sciences were advanced here and people’s lives were benefited in these facilities! 

I regret not spending more than an hour at this place, because it was worth twice as much time as the Park Guell.

I adore Sant Pau. It is one of the places I went most often, though I live here. I'm fascinated as it was bulid as an hosipatl and was an hospital until the 1980s (which is not that long ago). It is fascinating to see all the details in every little corner, to strive through the yard, to see how well thought everything was. I'm sure it is still very curing for all visitors to come to see THIS idea of an hospital, where in the center of the yard is the hall of operations, with huge windows and surrounded by beautifulness. For me it is THE perfect place to dive into modernismo and into the cocept behind: integreated, organic architecture on the basis of functionality: Form follows function. 
A loevely place. And a very calm place if you are in the yard. Love it!

This is much less crowded than the Sagrada Familia. The old hospital is a huge complex and provides visitors good information about the old time. It is a good place to take a rest by sitting in the big garden, listening to story about the one who constructed and designed the buildings as well as submerging into the tranquility. An audio guide is really good to help you recognize the structure of each building, its purpose, and the story behind it.

Take the time to drop by this stunner and walk around the gardens and different wings . The azulejos are astounding especially when the sun hits the windows and fills the rooms with reflections and colours ... a must !

The design philosophy and the reconstructed architecture of this site is incredible. A must stop visit if you want to see something really special. There are tours in English, if needed. Check the website. And go.

We spotted the Hospital when we saw some of the buildings from the bus of our hop on hop off tour and thought that it looked pretty interesting so decided to go and investigate further. So glad we did. This is an amazing place and not nearly as busy as the Sagrada Familia which is just a short walk away. Probably many people don't make the effort to come here, or may not even be aware of it, and that would be a shame. It was not built by Gaudi but by another modernista architect, and features similar whimsical turrets and towers with tiles, mosaics, glass and ironwork. Difficult to imagine that it was once a hospital but one of the buildings has been restored with hospital beds as it would have been originally. Lots of green space and gardens to sit in. The administration building is not to be missed as it is beautifully decorated. 
Our senior entry of €9.80 was well worth it.

I went here to kill time before my scheduled entrance time to Sagrada  Familia. I was a little reluctant to go in with a €14 fee but I am glad I took the chance. The architecture was amazing. The mosaic tiling was very beautiful. I was a little disappointed that many of the pavilions were not open as they were either private offices, under renovation or not yet renovated but the open pavilions and grounds made up for it. I would advise paying the extra €3 for the audio headset. Give yourself a good 2 hours to explore but it can be done quicker.

Awesome accomplishment for the care of the medically unfortunate.

The beauty, design and architecture is still amazing today. Must have been a small miracle 100 years ago.

Both the exteriors of the various buildings and interiors are magnificent. There is a lot to see and the crowds are smaller than some of the other architectural masterpieces in the city. Highly recommend.

Finally something really worth paying the entrance fee for. Don’t believe anyone who says don’t go in - the restored ceilings and pavilions are just stunning. The main pavilion with the pink doves and stained glass windows are beautiful. Easy to spend a good hour and a half here even with no audio guide. Don’t miss out on this one - you’ll also escape the crowds.
The Daily Telegraph rated this the secret wonder of Barcelona. It is a UNESCO world heritage site but is it worth the trip - yes, but only just. Art Nouveau - meh
The price seemed too high for me.. You can see a little bit from the outside, but not that much.. I didn't have a lot of time, so didn't spend the 14 euro to go in..

We actually didn't spend enough time to look at the full site (I was not well on that day).
The complex did look beautiful and I felt peaceful at the garden inside. But it was very windy on that afternoon.
I couldn't comment on more than what appeared to me in that hour.

As some other reviewer noted this is a stop on the tour buses but almost no one gets off here.  We did, took the self guided tour and were absoluted delighted.  Not a huge number of people (yet!!!) and plenty of good information to help you feel the architect's intent. This guy was every bit as good as Gaudi.  Oh, if only we thought about hospitals like this today!

You may not find this particular complex on any list of "must see" places in Barcelona.  However, it will soon be added I'm sure.  We had not heard about it until we arrived and had some extra time on our hands (believe it or not).  Our hotel staff suggested we come here.  Right now it's somewhat of a secret to visitors.  This is primarily because up until 2014, it was indeed primarily a hospital complex.  They've since built a new hospital nearby and converted this amazing space and opened it to the general public.  The complex consists of eight pavilions connected by beautiful walkways and landscape to a degree.  It has gone through several evolutions prior and was an original hospital for Barcelona, dating back to 1400's, and then redesigned in the 1920's Modernista style.  

While there are at least eight pavilions, not all are open to the public due to being occupied by various other organizations.  However, the ones that are open to the public are very interesting to spend time in.  In particular, you will want to make time to walk through the Exhibition Space pavilion that houses some great architecture and exhibits history of the complex.  Also, visit the Sant Rafael Pavilion and observe how the hospital/nursing wards actually looked like; it's quite interesting.  Also, you will want to walk through the underground tunnels which originally connected all these pavilions (fascinating).  You will actually see the staircases from the courtyard and go down to the tunnels.  Our last pavilion we thought was the most fascinating pavilion was the "Administration Pavilion".  I know, it sounds very dry, but it's indeed the most beautiful and largest of the pavilions in the complex, with its richly decorated and historical interior foyer.  

It's also not that far walking distance from Park Guell.  Do yourself a favor, and spend some time visiting this complex before it becomes overwhelmed with mobs of people.  When we were there, it was so nice not to have to deal with crowds of people.  It's like a historical sanctuary and secret to visitors.  It won't be like that for long.
This is so beautiful. We spent almost 2 hours to see it. The audiotour is really worth it and explains a lot of things very well (this is why we took so long :-)

Not far from Sagrada Familia, this Modernista complex is very interesting, mostrly from outside. Gardens are nice, mostly in summer, buidilng spread on a larg teritory. Documentation is good everywhere. Special mention to the Administration building, which is the nicest inside. It is open even on mondays.
This was a former hospital which is now partly a museum and a university building. It is well worth a visit and within walking distance of the Sagrada Familia.

One of the most beautiful architectural site that I have been fortunate to visit. Lovingly restored. It is easy to see why it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. We took the tour with a private guide who was able to relate the entire history. For some reason, very few people seem to know about it but it is just as spectacular as Sagrada Familia and Parc Guell. Not to be missed.

Spectacular unique architecture. We did the guided tour and were glad we did. We went early -- and it was really nice to almost have the place to ourselves. This is a MUST for those who are interested in architecture. The buildings were just amazing. I would have skipped this if someone hadn't said it was their favorite thing in Barcelona. It was high up on my list and I highly recommend it.

We were overwhelmed by not only the symmetry and beauty of the Modernisme design but by the truly progressive health care principles. A leading edge hospital of it's time. This complex demonstrates the best of the "form follows function" design principle in terms of patient care. It is well worth the extra few euros guided tour. Esther was knowledgeable and excited to share the stories, making the 90 minute tour fly by. It is obvious she has a deep pride in the amazing ongoing restoration that has occurred in the 10 years since it ceased its role as a hospital. Highly recommend adding this to your plans.

We decided to visit the holy cross hospital after the marvels of the Sagrada Familia. Contrary to the overcrowded Sagrada Familia, the Holy Cross Hospital is a welcome refugee for all that wish to admire the modernist architecture in piece. 

The hospital itself is an oasis of peace and quite. Renovations are still ongoing, but show already a lot of its former glory. Take into account that you will spend a few hours to see the whole site.

The hospital is located about 5-10 minute walk from Sagrada familia, the two buildings are on opposite sides of the road . you have a great view of the church from the hospital windows :) the hospital is so beautiful! It looks like a Harry potter campus or something from Disneyland. Its ai amazing that it was an actual hospital because the building is so gorgeous and the halls are so big. There's a new hospital building behind it that's now the hospital, they had to renew the building cause of new technology. But you can see when you walk around the old hospital pictures of how it looked when they still used it as a hospital with patients, operation halls and doctors.. Definitely worth a visit!!
Quieter than the bigger sites but still fascinating. Medical content interesting but main focus is the design

This beautiful, former hospital complex is only a few hundred metres from La Sagrada Familia but is lacking the crowds which thus allows a proper appreciation of its architectural, historical and social significance. It's excellent value too. 

Although the whole site is not open to visitors there are sufficient buildings open to understand the practical working of the hospital and to appreciate its amazing decor. Put it on your Barcelona 'to see' list.

I've been visiting Barcelona for many years. This space has been opened just a few years ago and it is amazing! Still quite unknown and not very visited... 
When I was a little girl I went to Hospital Sant Pau in an emergency room, so the transformation is amazing. Everything is clean and neat and you can really live the experience of this Modernism Architecture, and feel it!!!

We went to Hospital Sant Pau immediately after Sagrada Familia. Its is an easy 5-10 minute walk to the hospital and worth every minute!  We spent 2 more euros for a private tour (19 euro for two tickets). We were lucky enough to get Sebastian. He is so passionate about the history of the hospital and the history of Barcelona in general. My husband and I learned so much. So very interesting to learn about how health care evolved in the area. Ask Sebastian any question about his space and the time it was occupied and he could answer it. Such a unique and progressive way to
 care for the sick and what beautiful architecture created by the same man who did the Palau de la Musica Catalana.

The grounds and buildings are beautiful but security treated the paying guests very disrespectfully during Fashion Week.  We were consistently told to move on, could not use the rest rooms, and could not enter or exit through the main doors.  I was even told that I could not stand in certain spots.  My husband was not able to exit because only the fashion people could use the main entrance.  Why don’t you treat your paying guests as well as you treat the visitors who were hanging out drinking champagne and taking selfies?

This is the largest Art Nouveau complex in the world and really worth a visit if your in Barcelona. It's surprisingly quiet and there are rarely many tourists. Although the admission price is quite expensive you'll be seeing something beautiful which most visitors to Barcelona don't visit.

Sant Pau was a stop on the tour bus route, but I was informed that hardly anyone visits. What an architectural treat they are missing. The building is not by Gaudi, but Montaner, and there is beauty to be found both inside and outside of this site. There were hardly any people around, which made the experience even more enjoyable.

A great example of how such a practical building such as a hospital can be a conceived in the dreamy Art Nouveau style. The architect put forward some extremely modern concepts in this 100 year old hospital complex which was functioning till 10 years back!

The guided tour in english was very interesting, giving a comprehensive overview before you set out exploring the complex for yourself. The restoration is being carried out very tastefully. Definitely worth a visit if you’re into Art Nouveau!
If I think that that is and old Hospital, I would like to go back to be hill in even if.....Lluis Domènech I Montaner, was surely a man with genius and heart.

The complex is stunning on the exterior and the interior of the main building is also spectacular. The other buildings open to the public are not as interesting inside but still lovely from the outside. We had bought tickets in advance for a guided tour and the tour was 90 minutes long, which we felt was about 45 minutes too long as we were mostly interested in the architecture and the tour guide spent most of the time talking about the hospital history. We noticed plenty of people wandering around who were not part of a tour so I'd avoid the tour and just proceed at your own pace, especially as there's plenty of signage inside describing the uses of the buildings and the designs.

We took the time to walk to this are when we were in Barcelona.  It is simply magnificent in all aspects.  It is worth the walk.  It is a great piece of architecture and has lots of information to read while on the grounds.

Although it doesn’t (yet) receive many mentions in city guides, I’d say this art nouveau marvel ought to be high on the list of any Barcelona visitor’s must-do activities. The breathtaking restoration work and the superb audio guide combine to create a memorable wander through centuries of history and a unique insight into one man’s feat of architectural engineering. A hidden gem amongst this city’s many jewels.

Hospital Sant Pau is located very close to Sagrada Família. So you’d better see set of Sagrada Família and here. Not only beautiful architecture and also interesting history. I bought ticket on line beforehand, but it might be unnecessary, because you can buy ticket here and not so crowded with people.

Visited after our trip to the Sagrada Família. About 13 minutes walk away. This was an okd hospital for the poor that recently converted to a museum. Designed by Lluís Domènech i Montaner, who I believed was a professor of Gaudi? Nevertheless, there are beautiful architecture in the whole complex and really worth a visit. 14 Euros plus 3 if you want the audio guide.

This is an absolutely stunning looking building form the front entrance but very expensive to go inside at fourteen euros which I did not do. You can walk around to the right hand side and take photos through the gates and then carry on to the hospital grounds where you can get close to the perimeter fencing and get some more nice photos of the buildings.

While there are other buildings in Barcelona that are more popular, this building is well worth a visit, particularly if you are a photographer.  The building is striking architecturally and a visual treat.

It is little difficult to get to if one is walking but we found the trek to be worthwhile and a a chance to walk around less touristic parts of Barcelona.

I am a fan of the Barcelona modernisme architecture, and this place is the jackpot.  Book a guided tour and be in awe of the beauty and creativity of this historic hospital complex. This is truly a must-see site in Barcelona.

Go see this exquisite site - it is extraordinary and beautiful.  We spent 5 days in Barcelona, and this was our favorite.  The audio guide is extremely well done and helps pull it all together for the visitor.  A beautiful example of art nouveau/modernista design and turn-of-the-century concepts of urban planning in the post industrial revolution era.  Plan to spend 1.5-2 hours.
Amazing architecture and amazing colors! I couldn't believe it was a hospital before. Huge! Must see!

The entrance itself is already extremely beautiful and picture worthy. We entered with a student entrance fee of around 9 euros. General entrance fee is around 14 euros. The fact that it is a former hospital amazes me. There are probably around 5-6 buildings and you can enter most but some are closed to the public. You can still take see and take pictures from the outside. All have such beautiful architecture and are worth the visit. There is also an underground tunnel that allows you to travel from building to building which is probably how the staff used to transport patients. I was surprised that there were barely anyone in here which is what makes it underrated. I would recommend a 2 hour visit here.

Simply amazing. One of the most beautiful places I've visited in Barcelona. It was for a private event. Which I'm sure made the experience even more magical. This place is somewhere you should not miss out one if your a fan of the architecture of Barca.

Fee is €9.80 if you buy it there. The architecture is beyond amazing but there's nothing really much too do other than that. It's a great place to take picture, I can say that. The only sites that I like is the former operating room and the underground tunnel.

This complex of ornately designed buildings was a hospital until the 1960’s. Designed by one of Gaudís contemporaries - this is an absolute must for architect buffs. Apart from the well thought out design of the buildings with underground tunnels - the highlight is the spectacular detail of the various buildings. Amazing that a city would allocate such attention to a local hospital - a visit is definitely worth the effort.

It was easy to go there by Metro. The stop is hospital de Sant  Pau. There is a modern hospital outside the metro stop. You need to walk around the block to reach the museum. We just asked people where the museo is. 

The architect was the mentor of Gaudi. All the buildings are colorful. Inside there is an abundance of light. This hospital was built for indigent patients. Much thought went into how to make patients comfortable. 

We stayed here for about 2 hours ending our visit at the building where you can see the Sagrada Familia in the distance. Many tourists head to Sagrada Familia, Casa Mila and Park Güell. This is not as well known but definitely worth a visit.

We came here on a Sunday (Dec. 2) and somehow that day the entrance fee was waived.  Generally, it is 14 Euro or 19 Euro with a guided tour.  3 Euro for the audio guide.  Because we were tight on time, we skipped the guided tour.  (We came from Ayre hotel very close to Sagrada Familia - it was an easy walk to this place.) 

This complex of beautifully architected buildings (used to function as a hospital - not church) is worth viewing.  Sit in the garden and take a chance to sit down and enjoy the various facade!  As I understand, this was created by a contemporary of Gaudi 

The inside of the buildings may not contain as much information as you may want.  So a guided tour (or audio tour) may have helped.  

I definitely would recommend this place.  It will give you an idea of other designs other than Gaudi's.

This is a large place with each building so beautiful and intricate. The whole complex is serene and it was highlight of my trip. There is discount for those under 29. Completely worth the price. I would have taken the audio guide but it was raining. It is possible to go on a rainy day but one gets wet going to different buildings

It is also walking distance of Sagrada!

Hidden gem! Must visit. Found it better than Parc Guell
One of the best visits I’ve made.  Get the ‘headphone’ tour, well worth it.   No cafe on site (maybe i missed it). Expect to spend up to 2 hours here.
We walked through with the headset and were amazed. Well worth a visit. We spent about 3 hours - and enjoyed all of it! Incredible architecture and wonderful story of a man with a great vision.
